We tried to extend the PREP Act to cover industrial masks last week in the emergency-response bill. Pallone objected. Now, he’s refusing to pass the bill this week before the House recesses for a week and goes home.
There’s a simple answer: extend PREP to industrial masks. Right? Not if you’re @FrankPallone. Oh no.

The PREP Act protects medical-device makers from frivolous lawsuits during a public-health emergency, when we need to pull out all the stops. PREP covers surgical masks, but not industrial masks. So the mask makers are reluctant to provide industrial masks for medical users.
We have many, many more industrial masks than we do surgical masks. We need to get the industrial masks to our doctors and nurses, but there’s a problem.

Manufacturers of respirator masks make both surgical masks and industrial masks. The industrial masks don’t protect against bodily fluids (e.g., blood in trauma surgery), but they’re suitable against airborne particles, like the Wuhan coronavirus.
